header.title: A French Method of Fortune Telling

central_thesis: A.E. Waite presents a specific French method of fortune-telling utilizing a piquet deck of 32 cards, detailing the individual card significations (including upright and reversed meanings) and outlining practical operative procedures for various divinatory questions such as marriage, inheritance, legal matters, theft, and the fate of persons in prison or traveling. The text also briefly touches upon the historical origins of playing cards and implicitly contrasts the piquet system's simplicity with the deeper symbolism of Tarot.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to French Cartomancy and Card History
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the French method of card divination, noting its distinctiveness from English systems and its use of a piquet deck (32 cards). Waite traces the historical origins of playing cards, acknowledging their pre-existence in Spain and Italy before France, and hints at the Tarot as a more ancient and symbolically rich precursor. He emphasizes the necessity of French or Swiss cards with distinct upright and reversed markings for optimal practice.

Detailed interpretations for the Ace, King, Queen, Knave, Ten, Nine, Eight, and Seven of Diamonds are provided. Meanings range from 'Letters, or news' (Ace) to 'Good news, above all if accompanied by the Ace' (Seven). Reversed cards carry specific negative connotations, such as 'impediments, difficulties' for the King and 'inimical to the Querent' for the Queen.

This section outlines the meanings for the Ace, King, Queen, Knave, Ten, Nine, Eight, and Seven of Hearts. General themes include 'Joy, contentment' (Ace), 'Domestic and private happiness' (Eight), and 'Marriage' (Seven). Reversed cards typically indicate difficulties or negative traits, such as a 'miserly' King or 'obstacle to a projected marriage' for the Queen.

The interpretations for the Ace, King, Queen, Knave, Ten, Nine, Eight, and Seven of Spades are given, predominantly focusing on negative outcomes. The Ace, especially with the Ten and Nine, signifies 'death, grief', 'treason', or 'loss by theft'. Other cards denote 'disagreeable intervention' (King), 'disappointed woman' (Queen), 'disgrace' (Knave), 'imprisonment' (Ten), and 'quarrels, inquietude' (Seven), though the Seven can be ameliorated by Hearts.

Meanings for the Ace, King, Queen, Knave, Ten, Nine, Eight, and Seven of Clubs are detailed. These cards generally represent 'Advantages, commercial and industrial benefits' (Ace), 'influential, powerful person' (King), 'Success in love' (Nine), and 'favorable conclusion' (Eight). Reversed cards introduce obstacles or negative character traits, such as a King in 'danger of failure' or a Queen who is 'very covetous, jealous and disposed to infidelity'.

structure_content.chapter_title: I. Mode Of Operation: For Marriage and Similar Subjects
structure_content.summary: This chapter details a specific divinatory procedure for marriage questions. It involves selecting a 'Querent' card, shuffling and cutting the piquet deck, then dealing cards three by three to identify and extract 15 significant cards (or 21 in a variation). The presence of specific 'tierces' (three cards of the same suit in sequence) and Aces, determined by the Querent's complexion (dark/fair), dictates the outcome of marriage prospects, with specific conditions for country weddings and second marriages.

structure_content.chapter_title: II. Mode Of Operation: For Questions on Inheritance
structure_content.summary: The method for inheritance questions requires placing a Querent card and proceeding with shuffling and cutting. The key indicator for profit from a death is the upright Ace of Spades. This prospect is amplified by the presence of the Seven, Eight, Nine, and Ten of Clubs, indicating a large monetary increment.

structure_content.chapter_title: III. Mode Of Operation: For Lawsuits and Similar Matters
structure_content.summary: Divination regarding lawsuits hinges on the appearance of the King of Spades. The procedure is similar to others, involving shuffling and cutting. The completion of a 'quint major' in Spades (Ace, King, Queen, Knave, Ten) suggests a negative outcome for the Querent. Conversely, the presence of the four Tens promises excellent chances of success.

structure_content.chapter_title: IV. Mode Of Operation: For a Theft
structure_content.summary: To discover a thief, the presence of all four Knaves is deemed indispensable. The procedure remains the same. Specific card combinations reveal details about the thief: King and Eight of Spades suggest imprisonment, Ace of Spades indicates danger of death, and Ace of Clubs, King of Clubs, and Queen of Hearts imply restitution. A predominance of Diamonds suggests arrest on a different charge.

structure_content.chapter_title: V. Mode Of Operation: For a Person in Prison
structure_content.summary: This section outlines how to divine the chances of a captive's speedy liberation, with a selected card representing the imprisoned person. The Queen of Hearts, Knave of Clubs, Nine of Clubs, and the four Aces offer hope for easy liberation. Their absence signifies delay. The Eight and Nine of Spades, King of Spades, and Knave and Nine of Diamonds indicate significant obstacles and postponement.

structure_content.chapter_title: VI. Mode Of Operation: For Travelers
structure_content.summary: When divining for an absent traveler, a card is chosen to represent them. The appearance of the Ace of Hearts, Ace of Diamonds, and Ten of Diamonds indicates probable news, confirmed by the Seven of Diamonds. The Ten of Spades nearby suggests illness, while a reversed Ace of Spades warns of other dangers. Success in enterprise is indicated by the Nine of Hearts, Ace, and King of Clubs. The Eight of Diamonds signals a return. A variation of drawing 21 cards is mentioned, with red cards signifying great success.

Waite concludes by noting that while the piquet system is simple, fuller decks, particularly Tarot cards, offer 'incalculably superior symbolism' and are richer for cartomancy. He recommends against unnecessarily restricting the materials for intuitive interpretation, acknowledging that the 32 piquet cards lack the deep Kabalistic or magical significance of larger decks.

key_concepts.definition: A deck of 32 playing cards, consisting of the Ace, King, Queen, Knave, Ten, Nine, Eight, and Seven of each of the four suits, omitting cards from two to six.

The orientation of a card, indicating whether it is right side up (Droit) or reversed (Renverse), which significantly alters its divinatory meaning. This necessitates French or Swiss cards with full-length picture-pieces and marked numbers, or a student-modified English set.
The individual for whom the divinatory reading is being performed, often represented by a specific card drawn from the deck.
A specific combination of three consecutive cards of the same suit (e.g., King, Queen, Knave of Clubs), which holds particular significance in determining outcomes, especially in marriage questions.
A specific sequence of five consecutive cards of the same suit (e.g., Ace, King, Queen, Knave, Ten of Spades), which carries strong divinatory weight in certain inquiries, such as lawsuits.
The face cards (King, Queen, Knave) in a playing card deck, often bearing significant symbolic weight and representing individuals or influential forces in the Querent's life.
A method of divination using playing cards.

practical_system.description: The system is a form of cartomancy using a piquet deck of 32 cards. Its core mechanic involves interpreting individual card meanings based on their suit, rank, and orientation (Droit/Renverse, upright/reversed), alongside specific combinations and proximity to a designated 'Querent' card. The methodology is highly prescriptive, detailing precise steps for shuffling, cutting, dealing, and card selection depending on the nature of the inquiry (e.g., marriage, inheritance). The emphasis is on identifying key cards and specific card sequences (tierces, quints) among a pre-determined number of drawn cards (typically 15 or 21) to formulate a prognosis.
tools: A piquet deck of 32 playing cards (Ace, King, Queen, Knave, 10, 9, 8, 7 of each suit).

French or Swiss cards are preferred due to their full-length picture-pieces and explicit 'Droit' (upright) and 'Renverse' (reversed) markings for numbered cards. If using an English set, the student must manually mark the cards for orientation.
rituals: Cut the shuffled deck three times.
Select a single card to represent the Querent (or the person whose fortune is being told) and place it face-up on the table.
Deal the remaining cards out three by three.

For marriage questions: In each triplicity producing two cards of the same suit, select the higher-ranked card of that suit. Continue this process, reshuffling and cutting the rejected pile as needed, until 15 cards have been extracted and placed by the Querent's card. Interpret these 15 cards based on the presence of specific 'tierces' (e.g., King in Clubs for a dark man) and Aces, correlated with the Querent's complexion and desired outcome.

For other questions (Inheritance, Lawsuits, Theft, Person in Prison, Travelers): Follow the general shuffling and cutting procedure. The specific interpretation depends on identifying particular cards or combinations (e.g., Ace of Spades for inheritance, King of Spades for lawsuits, four Knaves for theft) among the drawn cards (typically 15, or 21 in an extended variation).
Interpret results based on specific card meanings, their Droit/Renverse orientation, proximity to other cards, and predetermined combinatorial rules for each type of query.

relevant_quotes.text: Important differences attach to the variations in question, so far as the trump-cards are concerned, as they do indeed in the English method.
It is indubitable, as I have stated already, that these were the precursors of our playing cards, but there are wide differences in most of the archaic sets.

French cartomancy in the eighteenth and nine-teenth centuries set the fashion to the whole English-speaking world, if not to Europe itself- that Alliette, or Etteilla, Mlle. Lenormand, Madame Clement and Julia Orsini were the prophets of all divination with all varieties of cards- and that, except in certain secret circles, where there is supposed to be a special tradition, we have done little more than follow them.
everything depends upon the insight, intuition, divining gift, or as it is called somewhat conventionally -- the clairvoyant faculty of the operator.

When the eye of the intuitive mind is open, it is well in things of this kind that the materials on which it can work should not be unreasonably restricted. The thirty-two piquet cards are not the two-and-thirty paths of the absolute according to Kabalism, and so there is no special magic in the lesser number, or if it resides anywhere deeply perdu it has not been given me to find it, a deficiency which I share apparently with those who invented the system, for they have certainly failed to adduce it.

critical_analysis.relevance: A.E. Waite's 'A French Method of Fortune Telling' serves as a crucial historical document in Western Esotericism, illustrating a specific practical system of cartomancy that predates the widespread modern popularization of Tarot. Its relevance lies in showcasing how divination was practiced using standard piquet decks, providing insight into early 20th-century occult practices and Waite's own comparative analysis of card systems. Waite, a prominent figure in Hermeticism and Qabalah, contextualizes this method within a broader magical landscape, implicitly advocating for the deeper symbolic resonance of Tarot while acknowledging the simplicity and historical precedence of piquet-based systems. It highlights the ingenuity of early diviners in deriving complex readings from a limited set of symbols and the emphasis on intuition as the ultimate divinatory faculty.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This text is highly relevant for academic researchers and practitioners of Western Esotericism, occultism, and magic, particularly those interested in historical cartomancy, the development of divinatory systems, and the works of A.E. Waite. It appeals to individuals seeking to understand pre-Tarot or parallel card divination traditions and to magicians interested in the operative mechanics of such systems, including the nuanced interpretation of card orientation and specific combinations for practical inquiries.
